title: Thunderbird Help
content: Hello, when I'm on a web site and choose to contact them, I click on their email. Instead of opening Thunderbird opening I get the annoying pop up that wants me to sign in and open the new Outlook. I do not use Outlook. I do not want to use Outlook. What do I need to do to simply have my Thunderbird open and completely ignore the Outlook? Thank you,
creator: eighthnote44

title: Unread email indicated in the Inbox, but cannot be found
content: In the left column, my Inbox, All Mail, and Important folders indicate that I have 2 unread emails. I can see those two emails in the All Mail folder, the Important folder, but I cannot see them anywhere in the Inbox. I do not have threads turned on in any of the folders. I have checked and tried all filters and sorts. I have tried copying the emails from the All Mail folder to the Inbox, with no changes. Any idea on how I can see them in the Inbox?
creator: johnmoster

title: Trying to set up Thunderbird which failed password check with or without password.
content:
Thunderbird failed password check with or without password. Cancelled to retry according to an online help and reran installation which brought up another donate page but refused amount less than original. Donating few more times without success is not realistic. How can I get past the Donate Page?

My first try was a new password because there was no indication of which was required.

The second attempt, the password I used was the serving email password for a POP3 server and 'checking password' lasted several minutes without success. Do I really have to have a password on account setup?

The Donate Page jail needs a bypass. The free software cost $25 so far.
creator: ibizcov5

title: How are images stored?
content:
How do I start…? Well, I’ll try from the beginning…

My C drive has almost run out of storage space. It only has between 1 and 2 GB left. When I receive emails in Thunderbird with (big) images, do these images eat of my C drive’s storage with the same proportion as the size of the images attached in the emails – i.e. if the image is 10 MB, will there then be 10MB less left of the C drive’s total storage space?

And is there any way to move the whole Thunderbird (emails with images) over to the D drive, which has plenty of storage space?
creator: TWIX
